13/* zlib.h -- interface of the 'zlib' general purpose compression library
14 version 1.2.8, April 28th, 2013
15
16 Copyright (C) 1995-2013 Jean-loup Gailly and Mark Adler
17
18 This software is provided 'as-is', without any express or implied
19 warranty. In no event will the authors be held liable for any damages
20 arising from the use of this software.
21
22 Permission is granted to anyone to use this software for any purpose,
23 including commercial applications, and to alter it and redistribute it
24 freely, subject to the following restrictions:
25
26 1. The origin of this software must not be misrepresented; you must not
27 claim that you wrote the original software. If you use this software
28 in a product, an acknowledgment in the product documentation would be
29 appreciated but is not required.
30 2. Altered source versions must be plainly marked as such, and must not be
31 misrepresented as being the original software.
32 3. This notice may not be removed or altered from any source distribution.
33
34 Jean-loup Gailly Mark Adler
35 jloup@gzip.org madler@alumni.caltech.edu
36
37 The data format used by the zlib library is described by RFCs (Request for
38 Comments) 1950 to 1952 in the files http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1950
39 (zlib format), rfc1951 (deflate format) and rfc1952 (gzip format).
40*/
41
42#ifndef ZLIB_H
43#define ZLIB_H
44
45#include "zconf.h"
46
47#ifdef __cplusplus
48extern "C" {
49#endif
50
51#define ZLIB_VERSION "1.2.8"
52#define ZLIB_VERNUM 0x1280
53#define ZLIB_VER_MAJOR 1
54#define ZLIB_VER_MINOR 2
55#define ZLIB_VER_REVISION 8
56#define ZLIB_VER_SUBREVISION 0
57
58/*
59 The 'zlib' compression library provides in-memory compression and
60 decompression functions, including integrity checks of the uncompressed data.
61 This version of the library supports only one compression method (deflation)
62 but other algorithms will be added later and will have the same stream
63 interface.
64
65 Compression can be done in a single step if the buffers are large enough,
66 or can be done by repeated calls of the compression function. In the latter
67 case, the application must provide more input and/or consume the output
68 (providing more output space) before each call.
69
70 The compressed data format used by default by the in-memory functions is
71 the zlib format, which is a zlib wrapper documented in RFC 1950, wrapped
72 around a deflate stream, which is itself documented in RFC 1951.
73
74 The library also supports reading and writing files in gzip (.gz) format
75 with an interface similar to that of stdio using the functions that start
76 with "gz". The gzip format is different from the zlib format. gzip is a
77 gzip wrapper, documented in RFC 1952, wrapped around a deflate stream.
78
79 This library can optionally read and write gzip streams in memory as well.
80
81 The zlib format was designed to be compact and fast for use in memory
82 and on communications channels. The gzip format was designed for single-
83 file compression on file systems, has a larger header than zlib to maintain
84 directory information, and uses a different, slower check method than zlib.
85
86 The library does not install any signal handler. The decoder checks
87 the consistency of the compressed data, so the library should never crash
88 even in case of corrupted input.
89*/
90
91typedef voidpf (*alloc_func) OF((voidpf opaque, uInt items, uInt size));
92typedef void (*free_func) OF((voidpf opaque, voidpf address));
93
94struct internal_state;
95
96typedef struct z_stream_s {
97 z_const Bytef *next_in; /* next input byte */
98 uInt avail_in; /* number of bytes available at next_in */
99 uLong total_in; /* total number of input bytes read so far */
100
101 Bytef *next_out; /* next output byte should be put there */
102 uInt avail_out; /* remaining free space at next_out */
103 uLong total_out; /* total number of bytes output so far */
104
105 z_const char *msg; /* last error message, NULL if no error */
106 struct internal_state FAR *state; /* not visible by applications */
107
108 alloc_func zalloc; /* used to allocate the internal state */
109 free_func zfree; /* used to free the internal state */
110 voidpf opaque; /* private data object passed to zalloc and zfree */
111
112 int data_type; /* best guess about the data type: binary or text */
113 uLong adler; /* adler32 value of the uncompressed data */
114 uLong reserved; /* reserved for future use */
115} z_stream;
116
117typedef z_stream FAR *z_streamp;
118
119/*
120 gzip header information passed to and from zlib routines. See RFC 1952
121 for more details on the meanings of these fields.
122*/
123typedef struct gz_header_s {
124 int text; /* true if compressed data believed to be text */
125 uLong time; /* modification time */
126 int xflags; /* extra flags (not used when writing a gzip file) */
127 int os; /* operating system */
128 Bytef *extra; /* pointer to extra field or Z_NULL if none */
129 uInt extra_len; /* extra field length (valid if extra != Z_NULL) */
130 uInt extra_max; /* space at extra (only when reading header) */
131 Bytef *name; /* pointer to zero-terminated file name or Z_NULL */
132 uInt name_max; /* space at name (only when reading header) */
133 Bytef *comment; /* pointer to zero-terminated comment or Z_NULL */
134 uInt comm_max; /* space at comment (only when reading header) */
135 int hcrc; /* true if there was or will be a header crc */
136 int done; /* true when done reading gzip header (not used
137 when writing a gzip file) */
138} gz_header;
139
140typedef gz_header FAR *gz_headerp;
141
142/*
143 The application must update next_in and avail_in when avail_in has dropped
144 to zero. It must update next_out and avail_out when avail_out has dropped
145 to zero. The application must initialize zalloc, zfree and opaque before
146 calling the init function. All other fields are set by the compression
147 library and must not be updated by the application.
148
149 The opaque value provided by the application will be passed as the first
150 parameter for calls of zalloc and zfree. This can be useful for custom
151 memory management. The compression library attaches no meaning to the
152 opaque value.
153
154 zalloc must return Z_NULL if there is not enough memory for the object.
155 If zlib is used in a multi-threaded application, zalloc and zfree must be
156 thread safe.
157
158 On 16-bit systems, the functions zalloc and zfree must be able to allocate
159 exactly 65536 bytes, but will not be required to allocate more than this if
160 the symbol MAXSEG_64K is defined (see zconf.h). WARNING: On MSDOS, pointers
161 returned by zalloc for objects of exactly 65536 bytes *must* have their
162 offset normalized to zero. The default allocation function provided by this
163 library ensures this (see zutil.c). To reduce memory requirements and avoid
164 any allocation of 64K objects, at the expense of compression ratio, compile
165 the library with -DMAX_WBITS=14 (see zconf.h).
166
167 The fields total_in and total_out can be used for statistics or progress
168 reports. After compression, total_in holds the total size of the
169 uncompressed data and may be saved for use in the decompressor (particularly
170 if the decompressor wants to decompress everything in a single step).
171*/
172
173 /* constants */
174
175#define Z_NO_FLUSH 0
176#define Z_PARTIAL_FLUSH 1
177#define Z_SYNC_FLUSH 2
178#define Z_FULL_FLUSH 3
179#define Z_FINISH 4
180#define Z_BLOCK 5
181#define Z_TREES 6
182/* Allowed flush values; see deflate() and inflate() below for details */
183
184#define Z_OK 0
185#define Z_STREAM_END 1
186#define Z_NEED_DICT 2
187#define Z_ERRNO (-1)
188#define Z_STREAM_ERROR (-2)
189#define Z_DATA_ERROR (-3)
190#define Z_MEM_ERROR (-4)
191#define Z_BUF_ERROR (-5)
192#define Z_VERSION_ERROR (-6)
193/* Return codes for the compression/decompression functions. Negative values
194 * are errors, positive values are used for special but normal events.
195 */
196
197#define Z_NO_COMPRESSION 0
198#define Z_BEST_SPEED 1
199#define Z_BEST_COMPRESSION 9
200#define Z_DEFAULT_COMPRESSION (-1)
201/* compression levels */
202
203#define Z_FILTERED 1
204#define Z_HUFFMAN_ONLY 2
205#define Z_RLE 3
206#define Z_FIXED 4
207#define Z_DEFAULT_STRATEGY 0
208/* compression strategy; see deflateInit2() below for details */
209
210#define Z_BINARY 0
211#define Z_TEXT 1
212#define Z_ASCII Z_TEXT /* for compatibility with 1.2.2 and earlier */
213#define Z_UNKNOWN 2
214/* Possible values of the data_type field (though see inflate()) */
215
216#define Z_DEFLATED 8
217/* The deflate compression method (the only one supported in this version) */
218
219#define Z_NULL 0 /* for initializing zalloc, zfree, opaque */
220
221#define zlib_version zlibVersion()
222/* for compatibility with versions < 1.0.2 */
223
224 /* basic functions */
225
226ZEXTERN const char * ZEXPORT zlibVersion OF((void));
227/* The application can compare zlibVersion and ZLIB_VERSION for consistency.
228 If the first character differs, the library code actually used is not
229 compatible with the zlib.h header file used by the application. This check
230 is automatically made by deflateInit and inflateInit.
231 */
232
233/*
234ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateInit OF((z_streamp strm, int level));
235
236 Initializes the internal stream state for compression. The fields
237 zalloc, zfree and opaque must be initialized before by the caller. If
238 zalloc and zfree are set to Z_NULL, deflateInit updates them to use default
239 allocation functions.
240
241 The compression level must be Z_DEFAULT_COMPRESSION, or between 0 and 9:
242 1 gives best speed, 9 gives best compression, 0 gives no compression at all
243 (the input data is simply copied a block at a time). Z_DEFAULT_COMPRESSION
244 requests a default compromise between speed and compression (currently
245 equivalent to level 6).
246
247 deflateInit returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not enough
248 memory, Z_STREAM_ERROR if level is not a valid compression level, or
249 Z_VERSION_ERROR if the zlib library version (zlib_version) is incompatible
250 with the version assumed by the caller (ZLIB_VERSION). msg is set to null
251 if there is no error message. deflateInit does not perform any compression:
252 this will be done by deflate().
253*/
254
255ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflate OF((z_streamp strm, int flush));
256/*
257 deflate compresses as much data as possible, and stops when the input
258 buffer becomes empty or the output buffer becomes full. It may introduce
259 some output latency (reading input without producing any output) except when
260 forced to flush.
261
262 The detailed semantics are as follows. deflate performs one or both of the
263 following actions:
264
265 - Compress more input starting at next_in and update next_in and avail_in
266 accordingly. If not all input can be processed (because there is not
267 enough room in the output buffer), next_in and avail_in are updated and
268 processing will resume at this point for the next call of deflate().
269
270 - Provide more output starting at next_out and update next_out and avail_out
271 accordingly. This action is forced if the parameter flush is non zero.
272 Forcing flush frequently degrades the compression ratio, so this parameter
273 should be set only when necessary (in interactive applications). Some
274 output may be provided even if flush is not set.
275
276 Before the call of deflate(), the application should ensure that at least
277 one of the actions is possible, by providing more input and/or consuming more
278 output, and updating avail_in or avail_out accordingly; avail_out should
279 never be zero before the call. The application can consume the compressed
280 output when it wants, for example when the output buffer is full (avail_out
281 == 0), or after each call of deflate(). If deflate returns Z_OK and with
282 zero avail_out, it must be called again after making room in the output
283 buffer because there might be more output pending.
284
285 Normally the parameter flush is set to Z_NO_FLUSH, which allows deflate to
286 decide how much data to accumulate before producing output, in order to
287 maximize compression.
288
289 If the parameter flush is set to Z_SYNC_FLUSH, all pending output is
290 flushed to the output buffer and the output is aligned on a byte boundary, so
291 that the decompressor can get all input data available so far. (In
292 particular avail_in is zero after the call if enough output space has been
293 provided before the call.) Flushing may degrade compression for some
294 compression algorithms and so it should be used only when necessary. This
295 completes the current deflate block and follows it with an empty stored block
296 that is three bits plus filler bits to the next byte, followed by four bytes
297 (00 00 ff ff).
298
299 If flush is set to Z_PARTIAL_FLUSH, all pending output is flushed to the
300 output buffer, but the output is not aligned to a byte boundary. All of the
301 input data so far will be available to the decompressor, as for Z_SYNC_FLUSH.
302 This completes the current deflate block and follows it with an empty fixed
303 codes block that is 10 bits long. This assures that enough bytes are output
304 in order for the decompressor to finish the block before the empty fixed code
305 block.
306
307 If flush is set to Z_BLOCK, a deflate block is completed and emitted, as
308 for Z_SYNC_FLUSH, but the output is not aligned on a byte boundary, and up to
309 seven bits of the current block are held to be written as the next byte after
310 the next deflate block is completed. In this case, the decompressor may not
311 be provided enough bits at this point in order to complete decompression of
312 the data provided so far to the compressor. It may need to wait for the next
313 block to be emitted. This is for advanced applications that need to control
314 the emission of deflate blocks.
315
316 If flush is set to Z_FULL_FLUSH, all output is flushed as with
317 Z_SYNC_FLUSH, and the compression state is reset so that decompression can
318 restart from this point if previous compressed data has been damaged or if
319 random access is desired. Using Z_FULL_FLUSH too often can seriously degrade
320 compression.
321
322 If deflate returns with avail_out == 0, this function must be called again
323 with the same value of the flush parameter and more output space (updated
324 avail_out), until the flush is complete (deflate returns with non-zero
325 avail_out). In the case of a Z_FULL_FLUSH or Z_SYNC_FLUSH, make sure that
326 avail_out is greater than six to avoid repeated flush markers due to
327 avail_out == 0 on return.
328
329 If the parameter flush is set to Z_FINISH, pending input is processed,
330 pending output is flushed and deflate returns with Z_STREAM_END if there was
331 enough output space; if deflate returns with Z_OK, this function must be
332 called again with Z_FINISH and more output space (updated avail_out) but no
333 more input data, until it returns with Z_STREAM_END or an error. After
334 deflate has returned Z_STREAM_END, the only possible operations on the stream
335 are deflateReset or deflateEnd.
336
337 Z_FINISH can be used immediately after deflateInit if all the compression
338 is to be done in a single step. In this case, avail_out must be at least the
339 value returned by deflateBound (see below). Then deflate is guaranteed to
340 return Z_STREAM_END. If not enough output space is provided, deflate will
341 not return Z_STREAM_END, and it must be called again as described above.
342
343 deflate() sets strm->adler to the adler32 checksum of all input read
344 so far (that is, total_in bytes).
345
346 deflate() may update strm->data_type if it can make a good guess about
347 the input data type (Z_BINARY or Z_TEXT). In doubt, the data is considered
348 binary. This field is only for information purposes and does not affect the
349 compression algorithm in any manner.
350
351 deflate() returns Z_OK if some progress has been made (more input
352 processed or more output produced), Z_STREAM_END if all input has been
353 consumed and all output has been produced (only when flush is set to
354 Z_FINISH), Z_STREAM_ERROR if the stream state was inconsistent (for example
355 if next_in or next_out was Z_NULL), Z_BUF_ERROR if no progress is possible
356 (for example avail_in or avail_out was zero). Note that Z_BUF_ERROR is not
357 fatal, and deflate() can be called again with more input and more output
358 space to continue compressing.
359*/
360
361ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateEnd OF((z_streamp strm));
362/*
363 All dynamically allocated data structures for this stream are freed.
364 This function discards any unprocessed input and does not flush any pending
365 output.
366
367 deflateEnd returns Z_OK if success, Z_STREAM_ERROR if the
368 stream state was inconsistent, Z_DATA_ERROR if the stream was freed
369 prematurely (some input or output was discarded). In the error case, msg
370 may be set but then points to a static string (which must not be
371 deallocated).
372*/
373
374/*
375ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateInit OF((z_streamp strm));
376
377 Initializes the internal stream state for decompression. The fields
378 next_in, avail_in, zalloc, zfree and opaque must be initialized before by
379 the caller. If next_in is not Z_NULL and avail_in is large enough (the
380 exact value depends on the compression method), inflateInit determines the
381 compression method from the zlib header and allocates all data structures
382 accordingly; otherwise the allocation will be deferred to the first call of
383 inflate. If zalloc and zfree are set to Z_NULL, inflateInit updates them to
384 use default allocation functions.
385
386 inflateInit returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not enough
387 memory, Z_VERSION_ERROR if the zlib library version is incompatible with the
388 version assumed by the caller, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the parameters are
389 invalid, such as a null pointer to the structure. msg is set to null if
390 there is no error message. inflateInit does not perform any decompression
391 apart from possibly reading the zlib header if present: actual decompression
392 will be done by inflate(). (So next_in and avail_in may be modified, but
393 next_out and avail_out are unused and unchanged.) The current implementation
394 of inflateInit() does not process any header information -- that is deferred
395 until inflate() is called.
396*/
397
398ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflate OF((z_streamp strm, int flush));
399/*
400 inflate decompresses as much data as possible, and stops when the input
401 buffer becomes empty or the output buffer becomes full. It may introduce
402 some output latency (reading input without producing any output) except when
403 forced to flush.
404
405 The detailed semantics are as follows. inflate performs one or both of the
406 following actions:
407
408 - Decompress more input starting at next_in and update next_in and avail_in
409 accordingly. If not all input can be processed (because there is not
410 enough room in the output buffer), next_in is updated and processing will
411 resume at this point for the next call of inflate().
412
413 - Provide more output starting at next_out and update next_out and avail_out
414 accordingly. inflate() provides as much output as possible, until there is
415 no more input data or no more space in the output buffer (see below about
416 the flush parameter).
417
418 Before the call of inflate(), the application should ensure that at least
419 one of the actions is possible, by providing more input and/or consuming more
420 output, and updating the next_* and avail_* values accordingly. The
421 application can consume the uncompressed output when it wants, for example
422 when the output buffer is full (avail_out == 0), or after each call of
423 inflate(). If inflate returns Z_OK and with zero avail_out, it must be
424 called again after making room in the output buffer because there might be
425 more output pending.
426
427 The flush parameter of inflate() can be Z_NO_FLUSH, Z_SYNC_FLUSH, Z_FINISH,
428 Z_BLOCK, or Z_TREES. Z_SYNC_FLUSH requests that inflate() flush as much
429 output as possible to the output buffer. Z_BLOCK requests that inflate()
430 stop if and when it gets to the next deflate block boundary. When decoding
431 the zlib or gzip format, this will cause inflate() to return immediately
432 after the header and before the first block. When doing a raw inflate,
433 inflate() will go ahead and process the first block, and will return when it
434 gets to the end of that block, or when it runs out of data.
435
436 The Z_BLOCK option assists in appending to or combining deflate streams.
437 Also to assist in this, on return inflate() will set strm->data_type to the
438 number of unused bits in the last byte taken from strm->next_in, plus 64 if
439 inflate() is currently decoding the last block in the deflate stream, plus
440 128 if inflate() returned immediately after decoding an end-of-block code or
441 decoding the complete header up to just before the first byte of the deflate
442 stream. The end-of-block will not be indicated until all of the uncompressed
443 data from that block has been written to strm->next_out. The number of
444 unused bits may in general be greater than seven, except when bit 7 of
445 data_type is set, in which case the number of unused bits will be less than
446 eight. data_type is set as noted here every time inflate() returns for all
447 flush options, and so can be used to determine the amount of currently
448 consumed input in bits.
449
450 The Z_TREES option behaves as Z_BLOCK does, but it also returns when the
451 end of each deflate block header is reached, before any actual data in that
452 block is decoded. This allows the caller to determine the length of the
453 deflate block header for later use in random access within a deflate block.
454 256 is added to the value of strm->data_type when inflate() returns
455 immediately after reaching the end of the deflate block header.
456
457 inflate() should normally be called until it returns Z_STREAM_END or an
458 error. However if all decompression is to be performed in a single step (a
459 single call of inflate), the parameter flush should be set to Z_FINISH. In
460 this case all pending input is processed and all pending output is flushed;
461 avail_out must be large enough to hold all of the uncompressed data for the
462 operation to complete. (The size of the uncompressed data may have been
463 saved by the compressor for this purpose.) The use of Z_FINISH is not
464 required to perform an inflation in one step. However it may be used to
465 inform inflate that a faster approach can be used for the single inflate()
466 call. Z_FINISH also informs inflate to not maintain a sliding window if the
467 stream completes, which reduces inflate's memory footprint. If the stream
468 does not complete, either because not all of the stream is provided or not
469 enough output space is provided, then a sliding window will be allocated and
470 inflate() can be called again to continue the operation as if Z_NO_FLUSH had
471 been used.
472
473 In this implementation, inflate() always flushes as much output as
474 possible to the output buffer, and always uses the faster approach on the
475 first call. So the effects of the flush parameter in this implementation are
476 on the return value of inflate() as noted below, when inflate() returns early
477 when Z_BLOCK or Z_TREES is used, and when inflate() avoids the allocation of
478 memory for a sliding window when Z_FINISH is used.
479
480 If a preset dictionary is needed after this call (see inflateSetDictionary
481 below), inflate sets strm->adler to the Adler-32 checksum of the dictionary
482 chosen by the compressor and returns Z_NEED_DICT; otherwise it sets
483 strm->adler to the Adler-32 checksum of all output produced so far (that is,
484 total_out bytes) and returns Z_OK, Z_STREAM_END or an error code as described
485 below. At the end of the stream, inflate() checks that its computed adler32
486 checksum is equal to that saved by the compressor and returns Z_STREAM_END
487 only if the checksum is correct.
488
489 inflate() can decompress and check either zlib-wrapped or gzip-wrapped
490 deflate data. The header type is detected automatically, if requested when
491 initializing with inflateInit2(). Any information contained in the gzip
492 header is not retained, so applications that need that information should
493 instead use raw inflate, see inflateInit2() below, or inflateBack() and
494 perform their own processing of the gzip header and trailer. When processing
495 gzip-wrapped deflate data, strm->adler32 is set to the CRC-32 of the output
496 producted so far. The CRC-32 is checked against the gzip trailer.
497
498 inflate() returns Z_OK if some progress has been made (more input processed
499 or more output produced), Z_STREAM_END if the end of the compressed data has
500 been reached and all uncompressed output has been produced, Z_NEED_DICT if a
501 preset dictionary is needed at this point, Z_DATA_ERROR if the input data was
502 corrupted (input stream not conforming to the zlib format or incorrect check
503 value), Z_STREAM_ERROR if the stream structure was inconsistent (for example
504 next_in or next_out was Z_NULL), Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not enough memory,
505 Z_BUF_ERROR if no progress is possible or if there was not enough room in the
506 output buffer when Z_FINISH is used. Note that Z_BUF_ERROR is not fatal, and
507 inflate() can be called again with more input and more output space to
508 continue decompressing. If Z_DATA_ERROR is returned, the application may
509 then call inflateSync() to look for a good compression block if a partial
510 recovery of the data is desired.
511*/
512
513ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateEnd OF((z_streamp strm));
514/*
515 All dynamically allocated data structures for this stream are freed.
516 This function discards any unprocessed input and does not flush any pending
517 output.
518
519 inflateEnd returns Z_OK if success, Z_STREAM_ERROR if the stream state
520 was inconsistent. In the error case, msg may be set but then points to a
521 static string (which must not be deallocated).
522*/
523
524 /* Advanced functions */
525
526/*
527 The following functions are needed only in some special applications.
528*/
529
530/*
531ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateInit2 OF((z_streamp strm,
532 int level,
533 int method,
534 int windowBits,
535 int memLevel,
536 int strategy));
537
538 This is another version of deflateInit with more compression options. The
539 fields next_in, zalloc, zfree and opaque must be initialized before by the
540 caller.
541
542 The method parameter is the compression method. It must be Z_DEFLATED in
543 this version of the library.
544
545 The windowBits parameter is the base two logarithm of the window size
546 (the size of the history buffer). It should be in the range 8..15 for this
547 version of the library. Larger values of this parameter result in better
548 compression at the expense of memory usage. The default value is 15 if
549 deflateInit is used instead.
550
551 windowBits can also be -8..-15 for raw deflate. In this case, -windowBits
552 determines the window size. deflate() will then generate raw deflate data
553 with no zlib header or trailer, and will not compute an adler32 check value.
554
555 windowBits can also be greater than 15 for optional gzip encoding. Add
556 16 to windowBits to write a simple gzip header and trailer around the
557 compressed data instead of a zlib wrapper. The gzip header will have no
558 file name, no extra data, no comment, no modification time (set to zero), no
559 header crc, and the operating system will be set to 255 (unknown). If a
560 gzip stream is being written, strm->adler is a crc32 instead of an adler32.
561
562 The memLevel parameter specifies how much memory should be allocated
563 for the internal compression state. memLevel=1 uses minimum memory but is
564 slow and reduces compression ratio; memLevel=9 uses maximum memory for
565 optimal speed. The default value is 8. See zconf.h for total memory usage
566 as a function of windowBits and memLevel.
567
568 The strategy parameter is used to tune the compression algorithm. Use the
569 value Z_DEFAULT_STRATEGY for normal data, Z_FILTERED for data produced by a
570 filter (or predictor), Z_HUFFMAN_ONLY to force Huffman encoding only (no
571 string match), or Z_RLE to limit match distances to one (run-length
572 encoding). Filtered data consists mostly of small values with a somewhat
573 random distribution. In this case, the compression algorithm is tuned to
574 compress them better. The effect of Z_FILTERED is to force more Huffman
575 coding and less string matching; it is somewhat intermediate between
576 Z_DEFAULT_STRATEGY and Z_HUFFMAN_ONLY. Z_RLE is designed to be almost as
577 fast as Z_HUFFMAN_ONLY, but give better compression for PNG image data. The
578 strategy parameter only affects the compression ratio but not the
579 correctness of the compressed output even if it is not set appropriately.
580 Z_FIXED prevents the use of dynamic Huffman codes, allowing for a simpler
581 decoder for special applications.
582
583 deflateInit2 returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not enough
584 memory, Z_STREAM_ERROR if any parameter is invalid (such as an invalid
585 method), or Z_VERSION_ERROR if the zlib library version (zlib_version) is
586 incompatible with the version assumed by the caller (ZLIB_VERSION). msg is
587 set to null if there is no error message. deflateInit2 does not perform any
588 compression: this will be done by deflate().
589*/
590
591ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateSetDictionary OF((z_streamp strm,
592 const Bytef *dictionary,
593 uInt dictLength));
594/*
595 Initializes the compression dictionary from the given byte sequence
596 without producing any compressed output. When using the zlib format, this
597 function must be called immediately after deflateInit, deflateInit2 or
598 deflateReset, and before any call of deflate. When doing raw deflate, this
599 function must be called either before any call of deflate, or immediately
600 after the completion of a deflate block, i.e. after all input has been
601 consumed and all output has been delivered when using any of the flush
602 options Z_BLOCK, Z_PARTIAL_FLUSH, Z_SYNC_FLUSH, or Z_FULL_FLUSH. The
603 compressor and decompressor must use exactly the same dictionary (see
604 inflateSetDictionary).
605
606 The dictionary should consist of strings (byte sequences) that are likely
607 to be encountered later in the data to be compressed, with the most commonly
608 used strings preferably put towards the end of the dictionary. Using a
609 dictionary is most useful when the data to be compressed is short and can be
610 predicted with good accuracy; the data can then be compressed better than
611 with the default empty dictionary.
612
613 Depending on the size of the compression data structures selected by
614 deflateInit or deflateInit2, a part of the dictionary may in effect be
615 discarded, for example if the dictionary is larger than the window size
616 provided in deflateInit or deflateInit2. Thus the strings most likely to be
617 useful should be put at the end of the dictionary, not at the front. In
618 addition, the current implementation of deflate will use at most the window
619 size minus 262 bytes of the provided dictionary.
620
621 Upon return of this function, strm->adler is set to the adler32 value
622 of the dictionary; the decompressor may later use this value to determine
623 which dictionary has been used by the compressor. (The adler32 value
624 applies to the whole dictionary even if only a subset of the dictionary is
625 actually used by the compressor.) If a raw deflate was requested, then the
626 adler32 value is not computed and strm->adler is not set.
627
628 deflateSetDictionary returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if a
629 parameter is invalid (e.g. dictionary being Z_NULL) or the stream state is
630 inconsistent (for example if deflate has already been called for this stream
631 or if not at a block boundary for raw deflate). deflateSetDictionary does
632 not perform any compression: this will be done by deflate().
633*/
634
635ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateCopy OF((z_streamp dest,
636 z_streamp source));
637/*
638 Sets the destination stream as a complete copy of the source stream.
639
640 This function can be useful when several compression strategies will be
641 tried, for example when there are several ways of pre-processing the input
642 data with a filter. The streams that will be discarded should then be freed
643 by calling deflateEnd. Note that deflateCopy duplicates the internal
644 compression state which can be quite large, so this strategy is slow and can
645 consume lots of memory.
646
647 deflateCopy returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not
648 enough memory, Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source stream state was inconsistent
649 (such as zalloc being Z_NULL). msg is left unchanged in both source and
650 destination.
651*/
652
653ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateReset OF((z_streamp strm));
654/*
655 This function is equivalent to deflateEnd followed by deflateInit,
656 but does not free and reallocate all the internal compression state. The
657 stream will keep the same compression level and any other attributes that
658 may have been set by deflateInit2.
659
660 deflateReset returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
661 stream state was inconsistent (such as zalloc or state being Z_NULL).
662*/
663
664ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateParams OF((z_streamp strm,
665 int level,
666 int strategy));
667/*
668 Dynamically update the compression level and compression strategy. The
669 interpretation of level and strategy is as in deflateInit2. This can be
670 used to switch between compression and straight copy of the input data, or
671 to switch to a different kind of input data requiring a different strategy.
672 If the compression level is changed, the input available so far is
673 compressed with the old level (and may be flushed); the new level will take
674 effect only at the next call of deflate().
675
676 Before the call of deflateParams, the stream state must be set as for
677 a call of deflate(), since the currently available input may have to be
678 compressed and flushed. In particular, strm->avail_out must be non-zero.
679
680 deflateParams returns Z_OK if success, Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
681 stream state was inconsistent or if a parameter was invalid, Z_BUF_ERROR if
682 strm->avail_out was zero.
683*/
684
685ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateTune OF((z_streamp strm,
686 int good_length,
687 int max_lazy,
688 int nice_length,
689 int max_chain));
690/*
691 Fine tune deflate's internal compression parameters. This should only be
692 used by someone who understands the algorithm used by zlib's deflate for
693 searching for the best matching string, and even then only by the most
694 fanatic optimizer trying to squeeze out the last compressed bit for their
695 specific input data. Read the deflate.c source code for the meaning of the
696 max_lazy, good_length, nice_length, and max_chain parameters.
697
698 deflateTune() can be called after deflateInit() or deflateInit2(), and
699 returns Z_OK on success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR for an invalid deflate stream.
700 */
701
702ZEXTERN uLong ZEXPORT deflateBound OF((z_streamp strm,
703 uLong sourceLen));
704/*
705 deflateBound() returns an upper bound on the compressed size after
706 deflation of sourceLen bytes. It must be called after deflateInit() or
707 deflateInit2(), and after deflateSetHeader(), if used. This would be used
708 to allocate an output buffer for deflation in a single pass, and so would be
709 called before deflate(). If that first deflate() call is provided the
710 sourceLen input bytes, an output buffer allocated to the size returned by
711 deflateBound(), and the flush value Z_FINISH, then deflate() is guaranteed
712 to return Z_STREAM_END. Note that it is possible for the compressed size to
713 be larger than the value returned by deflateBound() if flush options other
714 than Z_FINISH or Z_NO_FLUSH are used.
715*/
716
717ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflatePending OF((z_streamp strm,
718 unsigned *pending,
719 int *bits));
720/*
721 deflatePending() returns the number of bytes and bits of output that have
722 been generated, but not yet provided in the available output. The bytes not
723 provided would be due to the available output space having being consumed.
724 The number of bits of output not provided are between 0 and 7, where they
725 await more bits to join them in order to fill out a full byte. If pending
726 or bits are Z_NULL, then those values are not set.
727
728 deflatePending returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
729 stream state was inconsistent.
730 */
731
732ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflatePrime OF((z_streamp strm,
733 int bits,
734 int value));
735/*
736 deflatePrime() inserts bits in the deflate output stream. The intent
737 is that this function is used to start off the deflate output with the bits
738 leftover from a previous deflate stream when appending to it. As such, this
739 function can only be used for raw deflate, and must be used before the first
740 deflate() call after a deflateInit2() or deflateReset(). bits must be less
741 than or equal to 16, and that many of the least significant bits of value
742 will be inserted in the output.
743
744 deflatePrime returns Z_OK if success, Z_BUF_ERROR if there was not enough
745 room in the internal buffer to insert the bits, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the
746 source stream state was inconsistent.
747*/
748
749ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT deflateSetHeader OF((z_streamp strm,
750 gz_headerp head));
751/*
752 deflateSetHeader() provides gzip header information for when a gzip
753 stream is requested by deflateInit2(). deflateSetHeader() may be called
754 after deflateInit2() or deflateReset() and before the first call of
755 deflate(). The text, time, os, extra field, name, and comment information
756 in the provided gz_header structure are written to the gzip header (xflag is
757 ignored -- the extra flags are set according to the compression level). The
758 caller must assure that, if not Z_NULL, name and comment are terminated with
759 a zero byte, and that if extra is not Z_NULL, that extra_len bytes are
760 available there. If hcrc is true, a gzip header crc is included. Note that
761 the current versions of the command-line version of gzip (up through version
762 1.3.x) do not support header crc's, and will report that it is a "multi-part
763 gzip file" and give up.
764
765 If deflateSetHeader is not used, the default gzip header has text false,
766 the time set to zero, and os set to 255, with no extra, name, or comment
767 fields. The gzip header is returned to the default state by deflateReset().
768
769 deflateSetHeader returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
770 stream state was inconsistent.
771*/
772
773/*
774ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateInit2 OF((z_streamp strm,
775 int windowBits));
776
777 This is another version of inflateInit with an extra parameter. The
778 fields next_in, avail_in, zalloc, zfree and opaque must be initialized
779 before by the caller.
780
781 The windowBits parameter is the base two logarithm of the maximum window
782 size (the size of the history buffer). It should be in the range 8..15 for
783 this version of the library. The default value is 15 if inflateInit is used
784 instead. windowBits must be greater than or equal to the windowBits value
785 provided to deflateInit2() while compressing, or it must be equal to 15 if
786 deflateInit2() was not used. If a compressed stream with a larger window
787 size is given as input, inflate() will return with the error code
788 Z_DATA_ERROR instead of trying to allocate a larger window.
789
790 windowBits can also be zero to request that inflate use the window size in
791 the zlib header of the compressed stream.
792
793 windowBits can also be -8..-15 for raw inflate. In this case, -windowBits
794 determines the window size. inflate() will then process raw deflate data,
795 not looking for a zlib or gzip header, not generating a check value, and not
796 looking for any check values for comparison at the end of the stream. This
797 is for use with other formats that use the deflate compressed data format
798 such as zip. Those formats provide their own check values. If a custom
799 format is developed using the raw deflate format for compressed data, it is
800 recommended that a check value such as an adler32 or a crc32 be applied to
801 the uncompressed data as is done in the zlib, gzip, and zip formats. For
802 most applications, the zlib format should be used as is. Note that comments
803 above on the use in deflateInit2() applies to the magnitude of windowBits.
804
805 windowBits can also be greater than 15 for optional gzip decoding. Add
806 32 to windowBits to enable zlib and gzip decoding with automatic header
807 detection, or add 16 to decode only the gzip format (the zlib format will
808 return a Z_DATA_ERROR). If a gzip stream is being decoded, strm->adler is a
809 crc32 instead of an adler32.
810
811 inflateInit2 returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not enough
812 memory, Z_VERSION_ERROR if the zlib library version is incompatible with the
813 version assumed by the caller, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the parameters are
814 invalid, such as a null pointer to the structure. msg is set to null if
815 there is no error message. inflateInit2 does not perform any decompression
816 apart from possibly reading the zlib header if present: actual decompression
817 will be done by inflate(). (So next_in and avail_in may be modified, but
818 next_out and avail_out are unused and unchanged.) The current implementation
819 of inflateInit2() does not process any header information -- that is
820 deferred until inflate() is called.
821*/
822
823ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateSetDictionary OF((z_streamp strm,
824 const Bytef *dictionary,
825 uInt dictLength));
826/*
827 Initializes the decompression dictionary from the given uncompressed byte
828 sequence. This function must be called immediately after a call of inflate,
829 if that call returned Z_NEED_DICT. The dictionary chosen by the compressor
830 can be determined from the adler32 value returned by that call of inflate.
831 The compressor and decompressor must use exactly the same dictionary (see
832 deflateSetDictionary). For raw inflate, this function can be called at any
833 time to set the dictionary. If the provided dictionary is smaller than the
834 window and there is already data in the window, then the provided dictionary
835 will amend what's there. The application must insure that the dictionary
836 that was used for compression is provided.
837
838 inflateSetDictionary returns Z_OK if success, Z_STREAM_ERROR if a
839 parameter is invalid (e.g. dictionary being Z_NULL) or the stream state is
840 inconsistent, Z_DATA_ERROR if the given dictionary doesn't match the
841 expected one (incorrect adler32 value). inflateSetDictionary does not
842 perform any decompression: this will be done by subsequent calls of
843 inflate().
844*/
845
846ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateGetDictionary OF((z_streamp strm,
847 Bytef *dictionary,
848 uInt *dictLength));
849/*
850 Returns the sliding dictionary being maintained by inflate. dictLength is
851 set to the number of bytes in the dictionary, and that many bytes are copied
852 to dictionary. dictionary must have enough space, where 32768 bytes is
853 always enough. If inflateGetDictionary() is called with dictionary equal to
854 Z_NULL, then only the dictionary length is returned, and nothing is copied.
855 Similary, if dictLength is Z_NULL, then it is not set.
856
857 inflateGetDictionary returns Z_OK on success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the
858 stream state is inconsistent.
859*/
860
861ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateSync OF((z_streamp strm));
862/*
863 Skips invalid compressed data until a possible full flush point (see above
864 for the description of deflate with Z_FULL_FLUSH) can be found, or until all
865 available input is skipped. No output is provided.
866
867 inflateSync searches for a 00 00 FF FF pattern in the compressed data.
868 All full flush points have this pattern, but not all occurrences of this
869 pattern are full flush points.
870
871 inflateSync returns Z_OK if a possible full flush point has been found,
872 Z_BUF_ERROR if no more input was provided, Z_DATA_ERROR if no flush point
873 has been found, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the stream structure was inconsistent.
874 In the success case, the application may save the current current value of
875 total_in which indicates where valid compressed data was found. In the
876 error case, the application may repeatedly call inflateSync, providing more
877 input each time, until success or end of the input data.
878*/
879
880ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateCopy OF((z_streamp dest,
881 z_streamp source));
882/*
883 Sets the destination stream as a complete copy of the source stream.
884
885 This function can be useful when randomly accessing a large stream. The
886 first pass through the stream can periodically record the inflate state,
887 allowing restarting inflate at those points when randomly accessing the
888 stream.
889
890 inflateCopy returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not
891 enough memory, Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source stream state was inconsistent
892 (such as zalloc being Z_NULL). msg is left unchanged in both source and
893 destination.
894*/
895
896ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateReset OF((z_streamp strm));
897/*
898 This function is equivalent to inflateEnd followed by inflateInit,
899 but does not free and reallocate all the internal decompression state. The
900 stream will keep attributes that may have been set by inflateInit2.
901
902 inflateReset returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
903 stream state was inconsistent (such as zalloc or state being Z_NULL).
904*/
905
906ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateReset2 OF((z_streamp strm,
907 int windowBits));
908/*
909 This function is the same as inflateReset, but it also permits changing
910 the wrap and window size requests. The windowBits parameter is interpreted
911 the same as it is for inflateInit2.
912
913 inflateReset2 returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
914 stream state was inconsistent (such as zalloc or state being Z_NULL), or if
915 the windowBits parameter is invalid.
916*/
917
918ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflatePrime OF((z_streamp strm,
919 int bits,
920 int value));
921/*
922 This function inserts bits in the inflate input stream. The intent is
923 that this function is used to start inflating at a bit position in the
924 middle of a byte. The provided bits will be used before any bytes are used
925 from next_in. This function should only be used with raw inflate, and
926 should be used before the first inflate() call after inflateInit2() or
927 inflateReset(). bits must be less than or equal to 16, and that many of the
928 least significant bits of value will be inserted in the input.
929
930 If bits is negative, then the input stream bit buffer is emptied. Then
931 inflatePrime() can be called again to put bits in the buffer. This is used
932 to clear out bits leftover after feeding inflate a block description prior
933 to feeding inflate codes.
934
935 inflatePrime returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
936 stream state was inconsistent.
937*/
938
939ZEXTERN long ZEXPORT inflateMark OF((z_streamp strm));
940/*
941 This function returns two values, one in the lower 16 bits of the return
942 value, and the other in the remaining upper bits, obtained by shifting the
943 return value down 16 bits. If the upper value is -1 and the lower value is
944 zero, then inflate() is currently decoding information outside of a block.
945 If the upper value is -1 and the lower value is non-zero, then inflate is in
946 the middle of a stored block, with the lower value equaling the number of
947 bytes from the input remaining to copy. If the upper value is not -1, then
948 it is the number of bits back from the current bit position in the input of
949 the code (literal or length/distance pair) currently being processed. In
950 that case the lower value is the number of bytes already emitted for that
951 code.
952
953 A code is being processed if inflate is waiting for more input to complete
954 decoding of the code, or if it has completed decoding but is waiting for
955 more output space to write the literal or match data.
956
957 inflateMark() is used to mark locations in the input data for random
958 access, which may be at bit positions, and to note those cases where the
959 output of a code may span boundaries of random access blocks. The current
960 location in the input stream can be determined from avail_in and data_type
961 as noted in the description for the Z_BLOCK flush parameter for inflate.
962
963 inflateMark returns the value noted above or -1 << 16 if the provided
964 source stream state was inconsistent.
965*/
966
967ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateGetHeader OF((z_streamp strm,
968 gz_headerp head));
969/*
970 inflateGetHeader() requests that gzip header information be stored in the
971 provided gz_header structure. inflateGetHeader() may be called after
972 inflateInit2() or inflateReset(), and before the first call of inflate().
973 As inflate() processes the gzip stream, head->done is zero until the header
974 is completed, at which time head->done is set to one. If a zlib stream is
975 being decoded, then head->done is set to -1 to indicate that there will be
976 no gzip header information forthcoming. Note that Z_BLOCK or Z_TREES can be
977 used to force inflate() to return immediately after header processing is
978 complete and before any actual data is decompressed.
979
980 The text, time, xflags, and os fields are filled in with the gzip header
981 contents. hcrc is set to true if there is a header CRC. (The header CRC
982 was valid if done is set to one.) If extra is not Z_NULL, then extra_max
983 contains the maximum number of bytes to write to extra. Once done is true,
984 extra_len contains the actual extra field length, and extra contains the
985 extra field, or that field truncated if extra_max is less than extra_len.
986 If name is not Z_NULL, then up to name_max characters are written there,
987 terminated with a zero unless the length is greater than name_max. If
988 comment is not Z_NULL, then up to comm_max characters are written there,
989 terminated with a zero unless the length is greater than comm_max. When any
990 of extra, name, or comment are not Z_NULL and the respective field is not
991 present in the header, then that field is set to Z_NULL to signal its
992 absence. This allows the use of deflateSetHeader() with the returned
993 structure to duplicate the header. However if those fields are set to
994 allocated memory, then the application will need to save those pointers
995 elsewhere so that they can be eventually freed.
996
997 If inflateGetHeader is not used, then the header information is simply
998 discarded. The header is always checked for validity, including the header
999 CRC if present. inflateReset() will reset the process to discard the header
1000 information. The application would need to call inflateGetHeader() again to
1001 retrieve the header from the next gzip stream.
1002
1003 inflateGetHeader returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the source
1004 stream state was inconsistent.
1005*/
1006
1007/*
1008ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateBackInit OF((z_streamp strm, int windowBits,
1009 unsigned char FAR *window));
1010
1011 Initialize the internal stream state for decompression using inflateBack()
1012 calls. The fields zalloc, zfree and opaque in strm must be initialized
1013 before the call. If zalloc and zfree are Z_NULL, then the default library-
1014 derived memory allocation routines are used. windowBits is the base two
1015 logarithm of the window size, in the range 8..15. window is a caller
1016 supplied buffer of that size. Except for special applications where it is
1017 assured that deflate was used with small window sizes, windowBits must be 15
1018 and a 32K byte window must be supplied to be able to decompress general
1019 deflate streams.
1020
1021 See inflateBack() for the usage of these routines.
1022
1023 inflateBackInit will return Z_OK on success, Z_STREAM_ERROR if any of
1024 the parameters are invalid, Z_MEM_ERROR if the internal state could not be
1025 allocated, or Z_VERSION_ERROR if the version of the library does not match
1026 the version of the header file.
1027*/
1028
1029typedef unsigned (*in_func) OF((void FAR *,
1030 z_const unsigned char FAR * FAR *));
1031typedef int (*out_func) OF((void FAR *, unsigned char FAR *, unsigned));
1032
1033ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateBack OF((z_streamp strm,
1034 in_func in, void FAR *in_desc,
1035 out_func out, void FAR *out_desc));
1036/*
1037 inflateBack() does a raw inflate with a single call using a call-back
1038 interface for input and output. This is potentially more efficient than
1039 inflate() for file i/o applications, in that it avoids copying between the
1040 output and the sliding window by simply making the window itself the output
1041 buffer. inflate() can be faster on modern CPUs when used with large
1042 buffers. inflateBack() trusts the application to not change the output
1043 buffer passed by the output function, at least until inflateBack() returns.
1044
1045 inflateBackInit() must be called first to allocate the internal state
1046 and to initialize the state with the user-provided window buffer.
1047 inflateBack() may then be used multiple times to inflate a complete, raw
1048 deflate stream with each call. inflateBackEnd() is then called to free the
1049 allocated state.
1050
1051 A raw deflate stream is one with no zlib or gzip header or trailer.
1052 This routine would normally be used in a utility that reads zip or gzip
1053 files and writes out uncompressed files. The utility would decode the
1054 header and process the trailer on its own, hence this routine expects only
1055 the raw deflate stream to decompress. This is different from the normal
1056 behavior of inflate(), which expects either a zlib or gzip header and
1057 trailer around the deflate stream.
1058
1059 inflateBack() uses two subroutines supplied by the caller that are then
1060 called by inflateBack() for input and output. inflateBack() calls those
1061 routines until it reads a complete deflate stream and writes out all of the
1062 uncompressed data, or until it encounters an error. The function's
1063 parameters and return types are defined above in the in_func and out_func
1064 typedefs. inflateBack() will call in(in_desc, &buf) which should return the
1065 number of bytes of provided input, and a pointer to that input in buf. If
1066 there is no input available, in() must return zero--buf is ignored in that
1067 case--and inflateBack() will return a buffer error. inflateBack() will call
1068 out(out_desc, buf, len) to write the uncompressed data buf[0..len-1]. out()
1069 should return zero on success, or non-zero on failure. If out() returns
1070 non-zero, inflateBack() will return with an error. Neither in() nor out()
1071 are permitted to change the contents of the window provided to
1072 inflateBackInit(), which is also the buffer that out() uses to write from.
1073 The length written by out() will be at most the window size. Any non-zero
1074 amount of input may be provided by in().
1075
1076 For convenience, inflateBack() can be provided input on the first call by
1077 setting strm->next_in and strm->avail_in. If that input is exhausted, then
1078 in() will be called. Therefore strm->next_in must be initialized before
1079 calling inflateBack(). If strm->next_in is Z_NULL, then in() will be called
1080 immediately for input. If strm->next_in is not Z_NULL, then strm->avail_in
1081 must also be initialized, and then if strm->avail_in is not zero, input will
1082 initially be taken from strm->next_in[0 .. strm->avail_in - 1].
1083
1084 The in_desc and out_desc parameters of inflateBack() is passed as the
1085 first parameter of in() and out() respectively when they are called. These
1086 descriptors can be optionally used to pass any information that the caller-
1087 supplied in() and out() functions need to do their job.
1088
1089 On return, inflateBack() will set strm->next_in and strm->avail_in to
1090 pass back any unused input that was provided by the last in() call. The
1091 return values of inflateBack() can be Z_STREAM_END on success, Z_BUF_ERROR
1092 if in() or out() returned an error, Z_DATA_ERROR if there was a format error
1093 in the deflate stream (in which case strm->msg is set to indicate the nature
1094 of the error), or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the stream was not properly initialized.
1095 In the case of Z_BUF_ERROR, an input or output error can be distinguished
1096 using strm->next_in which will be Z_NULL only if in() returned an error. If
1097 strm->next_in is not Z_NULL, then the Z_BUF_ERROR was due to out() returning
1098 non-zero. (in() will always be called before out(), so strm->next_in is
1099 assured to be defined if out() returns non-zero.) Note that inflateBack()
1100 cannot return Z_OK.
1101*/
1102
1103ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT inflateBackEnd OF((z_streamp strm));
1104/*
1105 All memory allocated by inflateBackInit() is freed.
1106
1107 inflateBackEnd() returns Z_OK on success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the stream
1108 state was inconsistent.
1109*/
1110
1111ZEXTERN uLong ZEXPORT zlibCompileFlags OF((void));
1112/* Return flags indicating compile-time options.
1113
1114 Type sizes, two bits each, 00 = 16 bits, 01 = 32, 10 = 64, 11 = other:
1115 1.0: size of uInt
1116 3.2: size of uLong
1117 5.4: size of voidpf (pointer)
1118 7.6: size of z_off_t
1119
1120 Compiler, assembler, and debug options:
1121 8: DEBUG
1122 9: ASMV or ASMINF -- use ASM code
1123 10: ZLIB_WINAPI -- exported functions use the WINAPI calling convention
1124 11: 0 (reserved)
1125
1126 One-time table building (smaller code, but not thread-safe if true):
1127 12: BUILDFIXED -- build static block decoding tables when needed
1128 13: DYNAMIC_CRC_TABLE -- build CRC calculation tables when needed
1129 14,15: 0 (reserved)
1130
1131 Library content (indicates missing functionality):
1132 16: NO_GZCOMPRESS -- gz* functions cannot compress (to avoid linking
1133 deflate code when not needed)
1134 17: NO_GZIP -- deflate can't write gzip streams, and inflate can't detect
1135 and decode gzip streams (to avoid linking crc code)
1136 18-19: 0 (reserved)
1137
1138 Operation variations (changes in library functionality):
1139 20: PKZIP_BUG_WORKAROUND -- slightly more permissive inflate
1140 21: FASTEST -- deflate algorithm with only one, lowest compression level
1141 22,23: 0 (reserved)
1142
1143 The sprintf variant used by gzprintf (zero is best):
1144 24: 0 = vs*, 1 = s* -- 1 means limited to 20 arguments after the format
1145 25: 0 = *nprintf, 1 = *printf -- 1 means gzprintf() not secure!
1146 26: 0 = returns value, 1 = void -- 1 means inferred string length returned
1147
1148 Remainder:
1149 27-31: 0 (reserved)
1150 */
1151
1152#ifndef Z_SOLO
1153
1154 /* utility functions */
1155
1156/*
1157 The following utility functions are implemented on top of the basic
1158 stream-oriented functions. To simplify the interface, some default options
1159 are assumed (compression level and memory usage, standard memory allocation
1160 functions). The source code of these utility functions can be modified if
1161 you need special options.
1162*/
1163
1164ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT compress OF((Bytef *dest, uLongf *destLen,
1165 const Bytef *source, uLong sourceLen));
1166/*
1167 Compresses the source buffer into the destination buffer. sourceLen is
1168 the byte length of the source buffer. Upon entry, destLen is the total size
1169 of the destination buffer, which must be at least the value returned by
1170 compressBound(sourceLen). Upon exit, destLen is the actual size of the
1171 compressed buffer.
1172
1173 compress returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not
1174 enough memory, Z_BUF_ERROR if there was not enough room in the output
1175 buffer.
1176*/
1177
1178ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT compress2 OF((Bytef *dest, uLongf *destLen,
1179 const Bytef *source, uLong sourceLen,
1180 int level));
1181/*
1182 Compresses the source buffer into the destination buffer. The level
1183 parameter has the same meaning as in deflateInit. sourceLen is the byte
1184 length of the source buffer. Upon entry, destLen is the total size of the
1185 destination buffer, which must be at least the value returned by
1186 compressBound(sourceLen). Upon exit, destLen is the actual size of the
1187 compressed buffer.
1188
1189 compress2 returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not enough
1190 memory, Z_BUF_ERROR if there was not enough room in the output buffer,
1191 Z_STREAM_ERROR if the level parameter is invalid.
1192*/
1193
1194ZEXTERN uLong ZEXPORT compressBound OF((uLong sourceLen));
1195/*
1196 compressBound() returns an upper bound on the compressed size after
1197 compress() or compress2() on sourceLen bytes. It would be used before a
1198 compress() or compress2() call to allocate the destination buffer.
1199*/
1200
1201ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT uncompress OF((Bytef *dest, uLongf *destLen,
1202 const Bytef *source, uLong sourceLen));
1203/*
1204 Decompresses the source buffer into the destination buffer. sourceLen is
1205 the byte length of the source buffer. Upon entry, destLen is the total size
1206 of the destination buffer, which must be large enough to hold the entire
1207 uncompressed data. (The size of the uncompressed data must have been saved
1208 previously by the compressor and transmitted to the decompressor by some
1209 mechanism outside the scope of this compression library.) Upon exit, destLen
1210 is the actual size of the uncompressed buffer.
1211
1212 uncompress returns Z_OK if success, Z_MEM_ERROR if there was not
1213 enough memory, Z_BUF_ERROR if there was not enough room in the output
1214 buffer, or Z_DATA_ERROR if the input data was corrupted or incomplete. In
1215 the case where there is not enough room, uncompress() will fill the output
1216 buffer with the uncompressed data up to that point.
1217*/
1218
1219 /* gzip file access functions */
1220
1221/*
1222 This library supports reading and writing files in gzip (.gz) format with
1223 an interface similar to that of stdio, using the functions that start with
1224 "gz". The gzip format is different from the zlib format. gzip is a gzip
1225 wrapper, documented in RFC 1952, wrapped around a deflate stream.
1226*/
1227
1228typedef struct gzFile_s *gzFile; /* semi-opaque gzip file descriptor */
1229
1230/*
1231ZEXTERN gzFile ZEXPORT gzopen OF((const char *path, const char *mode));
1232
1233 Opens a gzip (.gz) file for reading or writing. The mode parameter is as
1234 in fopen ("rb" or "wb") but can also include a compression level ("wb9") or
1235 a strategy: 'f' for filtered data as in "wb6f", 'h' for Huffman-only
1236 compression as in "wb1h", 'R' for run-length encoding as in "wb1R", or 'F'
1237 for fixed code compression as in "wb9F". (See the description of
1238 deflateInit2 for more information about the strategy parameter.) 'T' will
1239 request transparent writing or appending with no compression and not using
1240 the gzip format.
1241
1242 "a" can be used instead of "w" to request that the gzip stream that will
1243 be written be appended to the file. "+" will result in an error, since
1244 reading and writing to the same gzip file is not supported. The addition of
1245 "x" when writing will create the file exclusively, which fails if the file
1246 already exists. On systems that support it, the addition of "e" when
1247 reading or writing will set the flag to close the file on an execve() call.
1248
1249 These functions, as well as gzip, will read and decode a sequence of gzip
1250 streams in a file. The append function of gzopen() can be used to create
1251 such a file. (Also see gzflush() for another way to do this.) When
1252 appending, gzopen does not test whether the file begins with a gzip stream,
1253 nor does it look for the end of the gzip streams to begin appending. gzopen
1254 will simply append a gzip stream to the existing file.
1255
1256 gzopen can be used to read a file which is not in gzip format; in this
1257 case gzread will directly read from the file without decompression. When
1258 reading, this will be detected automatically by looking for the magic two-
1259 byte gzip header.
1260
1261 gzopen returns NULL if the file could not be opened, if there was
1262 insufficient memory to allocate the gzFile state, or if an invalid mode was
1263 specified (an 'r', 'w', or 'a' was not provided, or '+' was provided).
1264 errno can be checked to determine if the reason gzopen failed was that the
1265 file could not be opened.
1266*/
1267
1268ZEXTERN gzFile ZEXPORT gzdopen OF((int fd, const char *mode));
1269/*
1270 gzdopen associates a gzFile with the file descriptor fd. File descriptors
1271 are obtained from calls like open, dup, creat, pipe or fileno (if the file
1272 has been previously opened with fopen). The mode parameter is as in gzopen.
1273
1274 The next call of gzclose on the returned gzFile will also close the file
1275 descriptor fd, just like fclose(fdopen(fd, mode)) closes the file descriptor
1276 fd. If you want to keep fd open, use fd = dup(fd_keep); gz = gzdopen(fd,
1277 mode);. The duplicated descriptor should be saved to avoid a leak, since
1278 gzdopen does not close fd if it fails. If you are using fileno() to get the
1279 file descriptor from a FILE *, then you will have to use dup() to avoid
1280 double-close()ing the file descriptor. Both gzclose() and fclose() will
1281 close the associated file descriptor, so they need to have different file
1282 descriptors.
1283
1284 gzdopen returns NULL if there was insufficient memory to allocate the
1285 gzFile state, if an invalid mode was specified (an 'r', 'w', or 'a' was not
1286 provided, or '+' was provided), or if fd is -1. The file descriptor is not
1287 used until the next gz* read, write, seek, or close operation, so gzdopen
1288 will not detect if fd is invalid (unless fd is -1).
1289*/
1290
1291ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzbuffer OF((gzFile file, unsigned size));
1292/*
1293 Set the internal buffer size used by this library's functions. The
1294 default buffer size is 8192 bytes. This function must be called after
1295 gzopen() or gzdopen(), and before any other calls that read or write the
1296 file. The buffer memory allocation is always deferred to the first read or
1297 write. Two buffers are allocated, either both of the specified size when
1298 writing, or one of the specified size and the other twice that size when
1299 reading. A larger buffer size of, for example, 64K or 128K bytes will
1300 noticeably increase the speed of decompression (reading).
1301
1302 The new buffer size also affects the maximum length for gzprintf().
1303
1304 gzbuffer() returns 0 on success, or -1 on failure, such as being called
1305 too late.
1306*/
1307
1308ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzsetparams OF((gzFile file, int level, int strategy));
1309/*
1310 Dynamically update the compression level or strategy. See the description
1311 of deflateInit2 for the meaning of these parameters.
1312
1313 gzsetparams returns Z_OK if success, or Z_STREAM_ERROR if the file was not
1314 opened for writing.
1315*/
1316
1317ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzread OF((gzFile file, voidp buf, unsigned len));
1318/*
1319 Reads the given number of uncompressed bytes from the compressed file. If
1320 the input file is not in gzip format, gzread copies the given number of
1321 bytes into the buffer directly from the file.
1322
1323 After reaching the end of a gzip stream in the input, gzread will continue
1324 to read, looking for another gzip stream. Any number of gzip streams may be
1325 concatenated in the input file, and will all be decompressed by gzread().
1326 If something other than a gzip stream is encountered after a gzip stream,
1327 that remaining trailing garbage is ignored (and no error is returned).
1328
1329 gzread can be used to read a gzip file that is being concurrently written.
1330 Upon reaching the end of the input, gzread will return with the available
1331 data. If the error code returned by gzerror is Z_OK or Z_BUF_ERROR, then
1332 gzclearerr can be used to clear the end of file indicator in order to permit
1333 gzread to be tried again. Z_OK indicates that a gzip stream was completed
1334 on the last gzread. Z_BUF_ERROR indicates that the input file ended in the
1335 middle of a gzip stream. Note that gzread does not return -1 in the event
1336 of an incomplete gzip stream. This error is deferred until gzclose(), which
1337 will return Z_BUF_ERROR if the last gzread ended in the middle of a gzip
1338 stream. Alternatively, gzerror can be used before gzclose to detect this
1339 case.
1340
1341 gzread returns the number of uncompressed bytes actually read, less than
1342 len for end of file, or -1 for error.
1343*/
1344
1345ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzwrite OF((gzFile file,
1346 voidpc buf, unsigned len));
1347/*
1348 Writes the given number of uncompressed bytes into the compressed file.
1349 gzwrite returns the number of uncompressed bytes written or 0 in case of
1350 error.
1351*/
1352
1353ZEXTERN int ZEXPORTVA gzprintf Z_ARG((gzFile file, const char *format, ...));
1354/*
1355 Converts, formats, and writes the arguments to the compressed file under
1356 control of the format string, as in fprintf. gzprintf returns the number of
1357 uncompressed bytes actually written, or 0 in case of error. The number of
1358 uncompressed bytes written is limited to 8191, or one less than the buffer
1359 size given to gzbuffer(). The caller should assure that this limit is not
1360 exceeded. If it is exceeded, then gzprintf() will return an error (0) with
1361 nothing written. In this case, there may also be a buffer overflow with
1362 unpredictable consequences, which is possible only if zlib was compiled with
1363 the insecure functions sprintf() or vsprintf() because the secure snprintf()
1364 or vsnprintf() functions were not available. This can be determined using
1365 zlibCompileFlags().
1366*/
1367
1368ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzputs OF((gzFile file, const char *s));
1369/*
1370 Writes the given null-terminated string to the compressed file, excluding
1371 the terminating null character.
1372
1373 gzputs returns the number of characters written, or -1 in case of error.
1374*/
1375
1376ZEXTERN char * ZEXPORT gzgets OF((gzFile file, char *buf, int len));
1377/*
1378 Reads bytes from the compressed file until len-1 characters are read, or a
1379 newline character is read and transferred to buf, or an end-of-file
1380 condition is encountered. If any characters are read or if len == 1, the
1381 string is terminated with a null character. If no characters are read due
1382 to an end-of-file or len < 1, then the buffer is left untouched.
1383
1384 gzgets returns buf which is a null-terminated string, or it returns NULL
1385 for end-of-file or in case of error. If there was an error, the contents at
1386 buf are indeterminate.
1387*/
1388
1389ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzputc OF((gzFile file, int c));
1390/*
1391 Writes c, converted to an unsigned char, into the compressed file. gzputc
1392 returns the value that was written, or -1 in case of error.
1393*/
1394
1395ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzgetc OF((gzFile file));
1396/*
1397 Reads one byte from the compressed file. gzgetc returns this byte or -1
1398 in case of end of file or error. This is implemented as a macro for speed.
1399 As such, it does not do all of the checking the other functions do. I.e.
1400 it does not check to see if file is NULL, nor whether the structure file
1401 points to has been clobbered or not.
1402*/
1403
1404ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzungetc OF((int c, gzFile file));
1405/*
1406 Push one character back onto the stream to be read as the first character
1407 on the next read. At least one character of push-back is allowed.
1408 gzungetc() returns the character pushed, or -1 on failure. gzungetc() will
1409 fail if c is -1, and may fail if a character has been pushed but not read
1410 yet. If gzungetc is used immediately after gzopen or gzdopen, at least the
1411 output buffer size of pushed characters is allowed. (See gzbuffer above.)
1412 The pushed character will be discarded if the stream is repositioned with
1413 gzseek() or gzrewind().
1414*/
1415
1416ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzflush OF((gzFile file, int flush));
1417/*
1418 Flushes all pending output into the compressed file. The parameter flush
1419 is as in the deflate() function. The return value is the zlib error number
1420 (see function gzerror below). gzflush is only permitted when writing.
1421
1422 If the flush parameter is Z_FINISH, the remaining data is written and the
1423 gzip stream is completed in the output. If gzwrite() is called again, a new
1424 gzip stream will be started in the output. gzread() is able to read such
1425 concatented gzip streams.
1426
1427 gzflush should be called only when strictly necessary because it will
1428 degrade compression if called too often.
1429*/
1430
1431/*
1432ZEXTERN z_off_t ZEXPORT gzseek OF((gzFile file,
1433 z_off_t offset, int whence));
1434
1435 Sets the starting position for the next gzread or gzwrite on the given
1436 compressed file. The offset represents a number of bytes in the
1437 uncompressed data stream. The whence parameter is defined as in lseek(2);
1438 the value SEEK_END is not supported.
1439
1440 If the file is opened for reading, this function is emulated but can be
1441 extremely slow. If the file is opened for writing, only forward seeks are
1442 supported; gzseek then compresses a sequence of zeroes up to the new
1443 starting position.
1444
1445 gzseek returns the resulting offset location as measured in bytes from
1446 the beginning of the uncompressed stream, or -1 in case of error, in
1447 particular if the file is opened for writing and the new starting position
1448 would be before the current position.
1449*/
1450
1451ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzrewind OF((gzFile file));
1452/*
1453 Rewinds the given file. This function is supported only for reading.
1454
1455 gzrewind(file) is equivalent to (int)gzseek(file, 0L, SEEK_SET)
1456*/
1457
1458/*
1459ZEXTERN z_off_t ZEXPORT gztell OF((gzFile file));
1460
1461 Returns the starting position for the next gzread or gzwrite on the given
1462 compressed file. This position represents a number of bytes in the
1463 uncompressed data stream, and is zero when starting, even if appending or
1464 reading a gzip stream from the middle of a file using gzdopen().
1465
1466 gztell(file) is equivalent to gzseek(file, 0L, SEEK_CUR)
1467*/
1468
1469/*
1470ZEXTERN z_off_t ZEXPORT gzoffset OF((gzFile file));
1471
1472 Returns the current offset in the file being read or written. This offset
1473 includes the count of bytes that precede the gzip stream, for example when
1474 appending or when using gzdopen() for reading. When reading, the offset
1475 does not include as yet unused buffered input. This information can be used
1476 for a progress indicator. On error, gzoffset() returns -1.
1477*/
1478
1479ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzeof OF((gzFile file));
1480/*
1481 Returns true (1) if the end-of-file indicator has been set while reading,
1482 false (0) otherwise. Note that the end-of-file indicator is set only if the
1483 read tried to go past the end of the input, but came up short. Therefore,
1484 just like feof(), gzeof() may return false even if there is no more data to
1485 read, in the event that the last read request was for the exact number of
1486 bytes remaining in the input file. This will happen if the input file size
1487 is an exact multiple of the buffer size.
1488
1489 If gzeof() returns true, then the read functions will return no more data,
1490 unless the end-of-file indicator is reset by gzclearerr() and the input file
1491 has grown since the previous end of file was detected.
1492*/
1493
1494ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzdirect OF((gzFile file));
1495/*
1496 Returns true (1) if file is being copied directly while reading, or false
1497 (0) if file is a gzip stream being decompressed.
1498
1499 If the input file is empty, gzdirect() will return true, since the input
1500 does not contain a gzip stream.
1501
1502 If gzdirect() is used immediately after gzopen() or gzdopen() it will
1503 cause buffers to be allocated to allow reading the file to determine if it
1504 is a gzip file. Therefore if gzbuffer() is used, it should be called before
1505 gzdirect().
1506
1507 When writing, gzdirect() returns true (1) if transparent writing was
1508 requested ("wT" for the gzopen() mode), or false (0) otherwise. (Note:
1509 gzdirect() is not needed when writing. Transparent writing must be
1510 explicitly requested, so the application already knows the answer. When
1511 linking statically, using gzdirect() will include all of the zlib code for
1512 gzip file reading and decompression, which may not be desired.)
1513*/
1514
1515ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzclose OF((gzFile file));
1516/*
1517 Flushes all pending output if necessary, closes the compressed file and
1518 deallocates the (de)compression state. Note that once file is closed, you
1519 cannot call gzerror with file, since its structures have been deallocated.
1520 gzclose must not be called more than once on the same file, just as free
1521 must not be called more than once on the same allocation.
1522
1523 gzclose will return Z_STREAM_ERROR if file is not valid, Z_ERRNO on a
1524 file operation error, Z_MEM_ERROR if out of memory, Z_BUF_ERROR if the
1525 last read ended in the middle of a gzip stream, or Z_OK on success.
1526*/
1527
1528ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzclose_r OF((gzFile file));
1529ZEXTERN int ZEXPORT gzclose_w OF((gzFile file));
1530/*
1531 Same as gzclose(), but gzclose_r() is only for use when reading, and
1532 gzclose_w() is only for use when writing or appending. The advantage to
1533 using these instead of gzclose() is that they avoid linking in zlib
1534 compression or decompression code that is not used when only reading or only
1535 writing respectively. If gzclose() is used, then both compression and
1536 decompression code will be included the application when linking to a static
1537 zlib library.
1538*/
1539
1540ZEXTERN const char * ZEXPORT gzerror OF((gzFile file, int *errnum));
1541/*
1542 Returns the error message for the last error which occurred on the given
1543 compressed file. errnum is set to zlib error number. If an error occurred
1544 in the file system and not in the compression library, errnum is set to
1545 Z_ERRNO and the application may consult errno to get the exact error code.
1546
1547 The application must not modify the returned string. Future calls to
1548 this function may invalidate the previously returned string. If file is
1549 closed, then the string previously returned by gzerror will no longer be
1550 available.
1551
1552 gzerror() should be used to distinguish errors from end-of-file for those
1553 functions above that do not distinguish those cases in their return values.
1554*/
1555
1556ZEXTERN void ZEXPORT gzclearerr OF((gzFile file));
1557/*
1558 Clears the error and end-of-file flags for file. This is analogous to the
1559 clearerr() function in stdio. This is useful for continuing to read a gzip
1560 file that is being written concurrently.
1561*/
1562
1563#endif /* !Z_SOLO */
1564
